feed.title: Combined summary - An overview of the cluster mempool proposal

entry.title: Combined summary - An overview of the cluster mempool proposal
entry.summary:
The dialogue addresses inefficiencies in Bitcoin's mempool clustering algorithm, particularly when a new transaction with a high fee rate arrives and necessitates the eviction of existing transactions. It discusses the potential for re-adding previously evicted transactions, indicating a need for optimization in the transition between mempool states.
An alternative cost-based eviction strategy is proposed, focusing on the Cost of Forgetting (CFR) to minimize the fees paid during eviction while managing mempool space effectively. This method's computational complexity and its trade-off with perceived benefits are acknowledged as points of concern.
The conversation also explores the challenges wallets face in making effective eviction decisions due to incomplete network information. It suggests addressing simpler scenarios before aiming for an optimal solution that may be unattainable. The concept of sibling eviction is introduced as an alternative to the current CPFP carveout rule, allowing higher fee transactions to replace those with the same unconfirmed parent within size limits.
The discussion notes economic implications and user experience, advocating for flexible mechanisms rather than strict rules and recognizing the importance of learning from unsuccessful ideas.
A blog post further examines the nuances of carveout transactions in Bitcoin, highlighting their role in enhancing Lightning Network efficiency. Carveouts allow certain transactions to bypass standard mempool restrictions, based on criteria such as size and the absence of additional unconfirmed ancestors. The system's flexibility is demonstrated by the possibility of multiple carveouts within a single cluster.
Incentive compatibility in fee rates is discussed, suggesting prioritizing higher fees at the top of the mempool, but acknowledging the lack of proven effectiveness against manipulation strategies like anti-pin strategies. The blog outlines the theoretical nature of "mempoolfullrbf" style Replace-By-Fee (RBF) and the necessity of thorough research before implementation.
When evaluating fee rate profitability across different mempools, the preferred method involves padding the smaller mempool for equitable assessment. The post calls for strict adherence to cluster size constraints and cautions against policies allowing exceptions.
Concerns about the deprecation of the CPFP carve-out rule and the absence of simple alternatives are expressed. A proposal for a new design in Bitcoin Core's mempool presents policy changes emphasizing cluster size and RBF rule updates. This design aims for better alignment with miner incentives through a fully sorted mempool, simplifying transaction organization and improving efficiency. Details and community feedback on this proposal can be found in the original write-up by Pieter Wuille (@sipa).
